repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Agricultural Research and
            Extension Project, Agricultural Research and Sector
            Investment Project, Northwest Mountainous Areas Development
            Project, and National Rural Finance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome of the Agricultural
            Research and Extension Project is rated as unsatisfactory,
            and sustainability is unlikely. Bank performance is rated
            unsatisfactory because a firmer line should have been taken
            on administrative restructuring. Borrower performance is
            rated unsatisfactory because of substantial delays during
            implementation. OED rates the outcome of the Agricultural
            Sector Investment Project as moderately satisfactory and
            sustainability is likely. Bank performance is rated
            satisfactory, reflecting the solid analytic underpinnings of
            the project and the generally adequate nature of
            supervision. Borrower performance is rated satisfactory,
            primarily because of the high commitment to the project. OED
            rates the outcome of the Northwest Mountainous Area
            Development Project as satisfactory and sustainability is
            rated likely because the participatory approach has built
            community ownership. The National Rural Finance
            Project's outcome is rated highly unsatisfactory
            because it failed to improve on the deficient approach and
            mixed performance of the projects that preceded it.
            Sustainability is rated unlikely based primarily on the weak
            loan recovery rate. Bank performance is rated highly
            unsatisfactory because of the design deficiencies (reflected
            in hurried preparation). Borrower performance is also rated
            highly unsatisfactory, reflecting on the government's
            failure to allow the National Agriculture Bank to function
            as a solvent commercial enterprise. Four important lessons
            were confirmed by this project experience: First, a
            piecemeal approach to reform-trying to effect small changes
            under the cover of a number of investment operations-offers
            little leverage and is therefore unlikely to work. Second,
            attempts to strengthen monitoring are futile if the
            performance indicators monitored are not linked to achieving
            significant outcomes. Third, decentralization is an
            important objective, but may be counterproductive if
            resources are spread too thinly. This is a particularly
            important issue for agricultural services, the structure of
            which needs to be rationalized. Fourth, where there have
            been several interventions which are cumulative in effect it
            is reasonable for evaluators to have higher expectations of
            development effectiveness and to be correspondingly more
            demanding in their search for evidence of effectiveness.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Northwest Mountainous Areas
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Northwest Mountainous
            Areas Development Project is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as substantial, Bank performance as highly satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance as satisfactory. Sustainable management
            of natural resources and the environment in the northwest
            region and in Tunisia generally will remain important goals
            in the near future and the long term. The successful
            implementation of this project has provided many important
            lessons which can contribute to the attainment of this goal.
            The key lessons include: To attain maximum impact, project
            funded research should be limited to topics which are an
            integral part of project activities, demand-driven, and
            consistent with the development objectives. Dissemination
            techniques that include local farmers can be successful if
            they are given adequate technical assistance. When dealing
            with small-scale farmers, techniques that take into account
            the entire production system are more likely to be adopted
            than those developed for a specific crop or ecosystem. When
            a project includes land consolidation it is important to
            provide incentive such as land titling. Participation of all
            stakeholders ensures the success of the participatory
            approach from the early stages of project preparation. The
            participatory approach requires flexible project budgeting.
            Women extension agents are necessary to ensure women's
            participation in projects.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Northwest Mountainous Areas
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project addresses the important
            problems of rural poverty and natural resource degradation.
            It will help restore sustainable range, forest and farming
            activities, reducing soil degradation, erosion and
            sedimentation in reservoirs as well as increasing
            productivity and incomes in this impoverished region of
            Tunisia.  By using a participatory approach, it will
            strengthen farmers' planning and implementation
            capacity, and improve the responsiveness of rural service
            agencies to farmers' needs.  The project will support
            development of a participatory approach to watershed
            rehabilitation in about 50 micro-catchments in the
            Governorates of Beja, El Kef, Siliana, Jendouba and Bizerte
            over a six-year period.  Treatments will be integrated
            across a micro-catchment, and selected and implemented with
            the participation of the local population.  Treatments will
            include improved range management, improved fodder
            production, soil and conservation works.  The project will
            also provide such basic infrastructure as feeder roads,
            potable water, health centers and schools.  The projects
            will strengthen the planning, coordination, and
            implementation capacity of the executing agency and village
            groups. The project will provide for demand-driven,
            short-term applied research to address key development
            constraints in the region.  The micro-enterprise development
            component will promote, on a pilot scheme basis, the
            development of the informal sector and the establishment of
            village credit associations. The Geographic Information
            Service (GIS) will support surveys and inventories,
            selection and management of conservation areas and
            monitoring and evaluation. The project will finance land
            surveys needed for land titling.
